natural problem: How many times does the digit 9 appear in the list of all integers from 1 to 500? (The number $ 99 $, for example, is counted twice, because $9$ appears two times in it.)
natural solution: The easiest approach is to consider how many times 9 can appear in the units place, how many times in the tens place, and how many times in the hundreds place. If we put a 9 in the units place, there are 10 choices for the tens place and 5 choices for the hundreds digit (including 0), for a total of 50 times.

Likewise, if we put a 9 in the tens place, there are 10 choices for the units place and 5 choices for the hundreds digit, for a total of 50 times. Since 9 cannot appear in the hundreds digit, there are $50+50=\boxed{100}$ appearances of the digit 9.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count :: "int list \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..500}. count (digits i) = card {j. j \<in> digits i \<and> j = 9}"
shows  "sum count {1..500} = 100"

shows  "card {n. n \<in> {1..500} \<and> count (digit_encode 10 n) 9 > 0} = 100"

a_4.formal problem:
This problem involves complex string and list manipulations and patterns that are not directly translatable to Isabelle/HOL. Isabelle/HOL is a theorem prover not a general-purpose programming language, and as such, it is not designed to handle such tasks.   fixes count_nine :: "int list => int"
  assumes h0 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..500}. count_nine (digits_of n) = (if '9' \<in> set (digits_of n) then 1 else 0)"
shows  "sum count_nine {1..500} = 100"

Please note the "digits_of" function which would convert a number to a list of its digits is not definable in Isabelle/HOL. This theorem is for illustrative purposes only and cannot be proven in Isabelle.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes digit_count :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. y >= 0 \<and> y < 10 \<longrightarrow> digit_count x y = count (digits x) y"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> digit_count x 9 = sum (digit_count i 9) {i. i \<in> {1..x}}"
shows  "digit_count 500 9 = 100"

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count_9 :: "nat list \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "count_9 = (\<lambda>xs. length (filter (\<lambda>x. x = 9) xs))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> 500 \<longrightarrow> count_9 (digits n) \<le> length (digits n)"
shows  "(\<Sum> n \<leftarrow> [1..500]. count_9 (digits n)) = 100"

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. count n = count_occurrences (digit 9) (integer_digits n)"
and h1 : "count 500 = 100"
shows  "\<Sum> n \<leftarrow> [1 .. 500] . count n = 100"

and h1 : "count 500 = 100"
